reviewText:
Blackbay Asylum is listed as horror adventure, but I would define it more as a horror-comedy adventure. Actually even a b-horror comedy in many ways due to the main character being full of one liners, puns, and juvenile humor at times. The game also reminds me a bit of the POSTAL series in the way it looks as well as the over the top gore in certain situations, not to mention the vulgarity in humor. SOLD.

Blackbay Asylum is a point and click adventure game at its heart, but most of my enjoyment came from the absurd humor. You are a psychopath and a serial killer that has been incarcerated in an asylum for the criminally insane. At the outset of the game you awaken in your cell with your only true friend, Teddy. He is your stuffed teddy bear and you think he is alive. You talk to him as if he were once in a while and care for him. He doesn't play much of a role past this other than some odd hallucinations you have later, but it gives you some insight into your childlike mind right from the start. You soon realize that your cell door is open and as you leave you find that there are no other inhabitants in the asylum besides you. Well...alive anywyas, or human. Your quest to escape the asylum is now underway.

You play as the pschopathic killer with his only true goal being one of escape. As you roam around the halls of the asylum you begin to uncover an occult element within the asylum that for some reason you decide you must solve and find out where it hails from! This is some of the silly in the game as the story combined with who you are as a protagonist doesn't really mesh. Why would this guy care, or why would he bother to look into this and try to stop it? There isn't much in the way of reason here, but that doesn't stop it from being fun!

Gore, vulgarity, and goofball humor follow you all the way through this tale. Most objects in the game world can be interacted with in some way. Well...they can be looked at and give you a bit of dialogue from the main character as he looks at them. Paintings will show his complete disdain for art in general, he will tell you how he doesn't believe in washing his hands in the sink you look at, and you will find out quickly that wooden boxes are useless! Our hero isn't a smart man, but he definitely enjoys the one liner. He also has a very dark sense of humor and leans heavily towards violence within it. He has a very childlike mind, but he can be quite clever in his quips at times as well. This dialogue from the protagonist is really the highlight of the game for me as it keeps you laughing throughout, but of course he makes you groan just as often.

This game has some interesting concepts and gameplay mechanics for an adventure title. It is designed like a point and click adventure game with the puzzles and the story elements where you play most of the game from an overhead view as you walk around the Blackbay Asylum, but certain chapters mix it up nicely and put you into first person mode! This isn't off putting at all. It is done very well and feels completely natural to go from the overhead to the first person views in certain levels. The first person levels actually lend to the horror elements and atmosphere better than the normal overhead view as well. While the graphics remind you some of the POSTAL series in the style, there are sections that have some creepy atomospheres. Sound helps to make these areas feel scary, and there are a couple sections that are very creepy with the use of drarkness, sound, and gore. The gore and violence is cartoonish for the most part with your character looking like a roided out weirdo covered in blood when you do get to see him most times, but the style fits fine and the graphics are fitting.

Like any point and click adventure sort you will have to solve an array of puzzles. Blackbay Asylum excels in the puzzle realm. I played the game without guides and found that I was writing things down on paper and referring to them later for puzzles. This is always something I enjoy about adventure games when I must work out" the puzzles in this way more than just pulling a lever here and there with no thought at all. The puzzles here are a good mix of using symbols
voteText: and many others. While most seem fairly logical
helpfulPercent: there are a few that are illogical such as the use of safe combinations. So just an FYI when it comes to using a combo safe lock...forget what you know about a traditional lock combo because this game doesn't abide by those. Turning a combo lock is MUCH more straightforward in game than it would be in real life. ;)\n\nCombat isn't a factor in the game really. You have a couple of scenes where you need to run away
votesHelpful: but other than that you don't have too much in the way of "fighting". There are some boss "fights"
votesTotal: but theese are actually done as puzzles rather than actual combat scenarios. The final boss is quite a unique battle I must say with several puzzle elements involved to win  he final battle. While I wouldn't say it was genius by any stretch
votesFunny: or even logical at all steps
commentsCount: it does offer a refreshing change to a boss fight that you won't see elsewhere.\n\nThe only major negative in the game is the lack of save features. The game saves when you complete a chapter. There are 10 chapters

As in any adventure game the time it takes to get through an area depends mostly on your ability to solve the puzzles. So even if you must quit in the middle of a chapter

reviewText:
Don't let the graphics fool you! This is a very good adventure game, well worth your time and money if you found yourself fascinated by the imagery and concept like I was. The story starts out simple, but as you progress it becomes clear there is more going on. The personality of the psychopath you play is quite amusing. Many objects in the game can be examined twice for humorous responses, and sometimes hints about what to do.

There are 10 chapters in all with varying length. If you don't use a guide the game will take 6 hours or more to beat (about 7 for me). I've personally found no bugs or glitches. What sound there is is well done and in certain places adds to the tension, as does the music. The game will occasionally switch to 1st person and this is done very well and further adds to the tension (this is first done in chapter 3, and if it had stayed in birds-eye view that section would not have been as interesting).

The meat of the game is indeed the puzzles. I admit I found myself stumped for awhile on several of them, but they are solvable without a guide. I did need a hint for one of them, and one particularly aggravating puzzle had me stumped for over 15 minutes. And this was just chapter 3! The puzzles continue to be challenging all the way to the end.

My only complaints are the numerous spelling and grammar errors, and the lack of a save anywhere feature. Otherwise I had a blast! I therefore recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of adventure games and wants something bloody and freaky.
voteText: 81 of 97 people (84%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
So far my experience in Blackbay Asylum has been a pleasant one.
The graphics have an old-school feeling to it, but are smooth and not clunky.
The humour the game has is reminiscent of B-movies and adds a welcome contrast to the otherwise serious and scary atmosphere of the game.
The puzzles are clever, but conquerable. Some are straight forward, others are trial and error and others definetely require you to think about it, so all in all a good balance as of yet.
And what I love most of all so far is that the game actually manages to scare me and I am glad to admit it. The scares are well spaced from one another and are varied. One in Chapter 2 comes out of nowhere and when you reach Chapter 3....well, let's just say I definetely wanted to chicken out" at one or two stages when my "Nope"-senses were tingling. The transitions from birds-eye view to first person definetely add to immerse yourself in the atmosphere and the scares.

As such I can definetely recommend this game."

reviewText: I LOVE games that open with a dumb little disclaimer. It either means they don't actually take themselves seriously, or they take themselves SO seriously that you shouldn't bother to. Blackbay Asylum is the former sort, mashing top-down and first-person adventure gaming together with a liberal sprinkling of incredibly silly design. There's a lot of humor to be found here... which clashes more and more with the game itself the further in you get.\n\nYou play as... um... I think his name is Doug? I'm not entirely sure because it's never consistent, but he's a 6'8 mass murderer with a teddy bear and a soft side. My take is that you're not really supposed to sympathize with or revile him
date: just laugh along with him. And that's easy
recommended: because he has a ton of genuinely funny lines while examining the many hotspots of the asylum. I knew we were going to get along fine when he found someone ripped in half and shoved into a bookshelf
hoursPlayed: and said "That's why I don't read."\n\nMost of the game is played from a top-down perspective
voteText: with you leading Doug around the grim halls to examine things
votesTotal: and maybe figure out why demons have ripped everyone else to pieces. The puzzles are generally very clear and well thought-out
votesFunny: though the top-down perspective can make it very hard to spot key elements on walls
commentsCount: or odd objects on tables or floors. I had a tricky time locating a puzzle box in one office because it looked like a tablecloth. Of course
column16: if you just click on everything it'll be less of an issue
column17: which you should to get more of Doug's musings.\n\nWhile the tone of the text is firmly tongue-in-cheek

column23: alternating between goofy lines from Doug and Unity horror tropes.\n\nThere's a certain trashy charm to Blackbay Asylum

column25: but probably unique enough to keep you on board if you know what to expect. The exploring and puzzling is good as long as you're a little meticulous about it

reviewText:
OverviewDisclaimer: Not sure what’s up with the hours listed. I’ve definitely played more than two, and I’ve finished the game.
Blackbay Asylum is an unapologetic horror game, played from a top-down (not isometric) perspective, which then later shifts to and from a first-person perspective. This is done by design, thus you do not have the option to change viewpoints. The game has several puzzles, which run the gamut from extremely easy to maddeningly difficult. The story is decent, and I quite enjoyed his escape and subsequent adventure.

It’s bloody, offensive and harkens back to a time before SJW’s had soapboxes like what the Internet has provided, but above all that, it’s quite a fun game. As for the disclaimer that pops up prior to playing, it’s not lying.

ProsDecent  story that is twisted and dark
Sound effects and music are both good
Decent graphics; they work well for the atmosphere of the game
Great imagery, very dark
Fairly lengthy and will take you a while
Environments are good and varied for the most part
Fun flavor text when examining some items; your character is truly insaneConsVoiceovers are not the greatest
Some puzzles are needlessly complex, and most of them don’t help you in any way whatsoever, even subtle clues
No save system; if you start a chapter, you need to finish it to save (chapters do have checkpoints, but not ones that you can load if you leave the chapter)
Tad expensive for what it isSummaryBlackbay Asylum is a decent game. It’s fun, but gets a bit repetitive, and is overly offensive. This is the kind of game that would give a “trigger warning”. It invokes the era of the mid to late 90s, but it does so while having decent puzzles and an interesting enough story that you’ll want to see it to the end.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rjK3pQfkzCw&list=UU7_-PLIhjsEBwIQXqKxmNpA
Blackbay Asylum, is a puzzle adventure game, with a horror based theme. The game may have a spook feeling to it, but it does not go out of its way to scare you. While yes, their is much gore in the game its not so graphic that you should be having issue with it.  Their are no jump scares in the game nor should their be as its an adventure, puzzle based game and horror is not their goal. The game is littered with puzzles, and yet you don't see the same one twice, sure I may come across a door that's locked and need to find the code but each time I need to find the code for the door the process is different.

The voice acting will not win any awards, and the cut scenes while all skip able are simple and short, broken up enough not to be an issue, or take you out of your immersion. They add to the experience and take nothing away, its very important to state the game does not hold your hand. The last time I took so many notes while playing an adventure, puzzle game I was playing Kings Quest over 14 years ago. The game is designed well in its levels and puzzles and how it combine's the two.

Does it have some issues with lack of options menu, yes, but besides some minor set backs, over all I found the game very challenging. It is an easy recommend but just make sure you don't mind taking notes and working for your progression, other wise you wont last five minutes.  Thanks for your viewership, for more reviews be sure to check out the channel here. http://www.youtube.com/user/SocioPyscho

reviewText: This game takes you back to a bygone era when people really didn't care about critical reception and could basically program a fever dream and sell it to the open public. I long for those long lost days of weirdness, though this is a taste of that checkered time gaming history. It has that Creepy PS1 game that wasn't meant to actually be creepy but somehow is anyway" thing going. There's also a Legacy of Kain meets Harvester vibe
date: but it doesn't quite feel like anything else."

reviewText: Blackbay Asylum is a throwback to classic Horror adventure games but will you want to play this game ? In Blackbay Asylum you play as Doug. Doug is a serial killer and as soon as he gets caught hes sent to Blackbay asylum the home for the criminally insane. One night Doug is able to leave the prison cell without anyone in sight. And we soon find out that the guards got murdered by roaming monsters and its up to you to get out of Blackbay. So how is this game ? Its a great game and worth the purchase without a doubt. The game is played in a top down perspective with a few execptions where it switches to first person. The game is like a point and click adventure game but you have free will where you want to go. The game works great. So lets go through the pros and cons. Pros: the game is relativly creepy and has great atmosphere. Great soundtrack. Simple and fun gameplay. But its an adventure game so it has puzzles. Now i feel like i have to talk about the puzzles. The puzzles go from relativly simple to head scratching in a heart beat. The game has some illogical puzzles which make the game hard to beat. And some items are easy to miss because theyre are placed in dark corners. The story is also great and has a few funny moments too. Cons: The game is also quite short and a few minor bugs. Overall If you like adventure games Blackbay asylum is a must buy because its a fun game non the less. Great atmosphere, great puzzles and overall a great game. I give Blackbay Asylum a 8.5/10\n\nFor more reviews follow Snort's Review curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText: I came across Blackbay Asylum while it was on sale. Being an avid horror lover, I figured why not give this game a chance; I am definitely not disappointed! I currently have nearly 5 hours on record while on Chapter 5, which for those unaware there are 10 Chapters included in the game. The graphics may not be the most amazing you have ever seen. However, you will not be disappointed as the game is packed with puzzles that will not only challenge you, but also test your ability to retain information.\n\nSome people have complained about typos" or the fact that there is no ability to save between levels (that's right folks - you have to beat the chapter or it won't remember your progress). Despite the whining of others out there
date: I found the typos to be apart of the game's charm as you are playing a psychotic killer who obviously is not the sharpest knife in the drawer
recommended: lol. I also want to mention that Doug has a very dry sarcastic personality
hoursPlayed: which can sometimes be downright hilarious as well as borderline offensive; you will see his personality is based on his limited understanding of the world and society in general.\n\nAlso
voteText: the inability to save challenged me to focus and complete a chapter either in one sitting or retain where all the clues were so when I came back through I could catch-up to where I was quickly. Thus

reviewText:
Sick, gory, disturbing, twisted and very enjoyable game with lots of dark humor.


However, there are parts of the game played in 1st person which can cause extreme motion sickness  to some people due to very low FOV. I recommend playing in windowed mode/smaller resolution to overcome these parts if you are susceptible.

Appart from that, it was very refreshing and enjoyable experience.

10/10

reviewText: EDIT: They have updated the game, and now every single complaint I had about the game is completely gone. Well done, guys! This game rocks.\n----------\nI have not gotten to play very much of this game; my only complaint is the controls. Otherwise, it's grim, grotesque, bloody, gory, delightful play. I wish it were more forgiving; I hate having to restart a chapter when I die (especially because the crappy controls are the reason behind EVERY ONE OF MY DEATHS, but I recommend this game to anyone in the hope that they'll someday fix the shoddy control system. The story, the puzzles, the atmosphere are all perfect, outside of a small number of grammatical errors and typos. One of my favorite games I've gotten on Steam...just need Run to extend to the /right shift/ key, instead of confining it to /left shift./

reviewText:
Cool game if you're into the whole Lovecraft Mythos and all that, or if you're just into dark humor and horror themed events,  There's nothing really scary here but it's just a visual treat for the gaming demented (you know who you are).  The puzzles aren't mind-bending but a few did stump me and that's what the internet walkthroughs are for.

My only complaint is the lack of save game options during a couple of the long chapters, but it's no deal-breaker.

Oh, and not to spoil, but the ahem" action taken against the crippled janitor is priceless.

8/10 ------- Good Times"

reviewText:
I've been interested in this game since I saw Jim Sterlings greenlight video mocking it. Twenty dollars was too rich a gamble for me, seeing it on sale for 5 though I bought it immediately. No regrets.

It's a funny little puzzle adventure game with early nineties PC graphics. They're not beautiful, in fact they're really ugly but they fit well with the games flippant attitude. Doug, our protaganist, is the mouthpiece for the majority of the game and to be honest I thought his goofball one-liners were really at odd with who he is but whatever. The game doesn't take its self seriously so why should I?

The puzzles are pretty good. The first few are infantile but they get harder and more interesting. Sometimes you'll get stuck because you missed an item which is a common failing of Point-and-Clicks. But to be fair this is not a Point-and-Click, its a Move-and-Push-Space and Doug is one bigass cursor. So comparitivily it's a little easier to find things you missed.

My only solid complaint is the voice acting, it's terrible. Doug is mercifully mute but you meet NPCs whose voices are somehow both obnoxious and boring. I can't skip through their dialouge fast enough!

I still dont think its worth twenty dollars but it was a fine game for five.

reviewText:
Just completed the game. Here are my thoughts.
I generally give a traditional 10 point rating but I can't settle on any number for this game. I think recommend/not recommend is suitable for this game.

Pros:
Puzzles are fun and make sense
Good use of top down and first person viewpoints
Alright atmosphere for a game like this
Storyline isn't anything earth shattering, but it was interesting enough as to not deter me from playing the game
The music isn't terrible, though at times I think it induced a headache.
The graphics work
Somewhat of a twist-ending
Voice acting isn't half bad but definitely not amazing

Cons:
The graphics work... but at times they are pretty horrible
Overall, this game is pretty screwed up. Some may like it, some may not (I'm personally not big on effed up gruesome scenarios as found in this game, although they are probably welcomed in games of the like. So, this could be taken as a positive even.)

Overall, I would say if you are looking for a game with good puzzles and a bunch of screwed up content, this is the game for you.

reviewText: I'm not the biggest adventure game fan usually due to obtuse puzzles where you are forced to connect dots where there are none. This game, however, really got its hooks into me and I enjoyed every minute of it. Almost every puzzle feels natural and serves a real purpose in the adventure. You are given enough clues to be able to figure out what you need to do next and then it just comes down to using your brain to decode the mystery or having and observant eye. Recommended.

reviewText:
I saw the Jim Sterling video about the trailer of this game. He probably made fun of it because the game looks terrible. And let's be honest, the graphics of this game are pretty awful. Animations are pretty ♥♥♥♥ too.

However, the idea behind the game interested me so much that I bought the game. And it was very entertaining from start to finish!

I'm usually not the puzzle-kind-of-guy, but the puzzles in this game were pretty understandable and fun to solve. The rest of the gameplay is your typical run around and discover what items to pick up and how to use them.

The best part about this game is the story. Being inspired by H.P. Lovecraft, there are very interesting (and disturbing) things that you find out about Black Bay Asylum. I'm not gonna spoil it, but it was an exciting time I had with the game, and every new unlocked part of the game made me more interested to find out what's happening next.

Another very fun thing about this game is the protagonist. Playing a psychopath opens some interesting ways to solve some puzzles. Also, Doug has funny lines even for some very mundane things, which keeps the game interesting, even if you are just running around clicking on random stuff.

Two major flaws that I want to mention:
1. I don't like how some puzzles can actually kill you if you fail. This happens only 2-3 times in the game, but I don't like to re-do stuff, just because I didn't do it in the arbitrary way the dev wants me to.
2. There are no save-games in this game. So if you start a chapter, you should make sure you complete it in one sitting, because the game only saves whatever chapter you have unlocked.

But even those flaws (while being a bit of annoying) did not lower the fun I had while playing.

Overall I can recommend this game to anyone who is interested in the obscure story and doesn't care if the game looks like from the early PS1 era.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game is not worth full price. 20€ is far too steep a price for titles such as Blackbay Asylum, a crass and ugly game that proudly tries to set itself by the mere basis of being edgy. With FMVs that are the graphical equivalent of the first MediEvil released in 1998 for the PlayStation (just way uglier and devoid of personality), the game is bereft of a soul. Its main strength comes from its humour which, to be fair, is largely hit or miss (mostly miss). If your sense of humour revolves around the idea that observing how security guards possessing pornographic magazines is hilarious then Blackbay Asylum is going to be a non-stop hoot and holler for you. That is, if you can ignore the many grammatical and spelling errors that litter this game.\n\nIts inspirations are clear but none of them are treated with respect. I recognised at least two or three puzzles directly copied from Sanitarium. H. P. Lovecraft's works serve mostly as a thematic concept for the visual design of the monsters and the story itself (which is then all thrown out the window at the end anyway). Other segments in the game - where you are forced to switch from a bird's-eye-view to first-person - come across as an unnavigable dime a dozen white mouldy corridor walking simulator" rendition of SCP (if SCP actually was bad). I cannot express how clunky and mishandled this segment was
date: especially after it followed a childish but unique experience beforehand that made me respect the game to a degree. Additionally
recommended: there is no option for the player to change the brightness in the pause menu. I do not wish or try to be mean but this was easily one of the most annoying sequences I have ever played through in a video game. All this coupled with the fact that there exists no option for saving your game and that it does not feature a decent checkpoint system
hoursPlayed: and you're condemned to prolong your exposure to this game by retrying an entire level from scratch if you mess up.\n\nNevertheless
voteText: there are certainly segments in the game that show the developers' potential for creating a far better game than Blackbay Asylum ever could be. It  has some jokes that actually hit well
helpfulPercent: sometimes features interesting puzzle designs and has moments where there are some clever bits of storytelling through its environment. Unfortunately
votesHelpful: it is all bogged down by its own nature. It is a disorganised
votesFunny: mean-spirited and (at best) a barely subpar mess. Blackbay Asylum wears its hideousness as a badge of pride then forces you to respect it
commentsCount: but ultimately fails to offer anything of merit in return beyond the emptiness that is its creative bankruptcy."

I could speak a little about the story, but I'll save myself (and you) the time of reading the same thing you'll read in the game's description, that's more then you really need to know, considering that the story is so horribly uninteresting. That said, the game does offer lots of cheap amusement at the comments and things that the main character makes fun off throughout the game, being a horrror game though, it offers too little on that front, aside from a few, very sporadic tense moments and one section that's in first person through a very creepy, hell-like room, there really isn't much else that makes the horror aspect of the game stand out".

The gameplay is standard-fare

reviewText:
This is a pretty niché title, and I strongly believe would only really be enjoyed by a select sort of gamer. Let's look at the basics. It's a very old school looking top down (and occasionally First Person) adventure title. Gory and silly humour, horror theme, and plenty of puzzles along the way. The puzzles are generally fair (only ever found 1 that the clues, or lack thereof, weren't good enough for me to understand), and the story is just silly enough to keep you interested throughout the campaign.

The bad, however, are fairly obvious things. Firstly, it's a very old school game. Meaning the gameplay is a little clunky, the action sequences can frustrate, and the graphics are notably dated. It's also a fairly short game. Almost all of the chapters can be completed within about 10-20 minutes. The only exceptions are longer because the actual gameplay takes longer (such as the first person sections, where the movement is quite annoyingly slow).

Those things aside though, I had fun with it, and for the price, I can't really argue with the length or gameplay quality. This is the kind of game that people who still revel in retro would find enjoyable. You have to push past the annoyances to get to the fun, but the fun is there.

reviewText:
At first when I say this game I wasn't to sure if I should buy it or not but seeing it on sale I decided to give it a try, and you know what I didn't regret my purchase.  For instance Blackbay Asylum starts you off in a birds-eye view perspective then depending on the chapter or/and situation will automatically switch you to a first-person view; then once you complete the chapter or complete a certain task in the game it switches back to birds-eye view which along with the graphics doesn’t clash with the overall gaming experience instead it enhances it.  While the game itself has sick twisted sense of humor to it that can be very funny at times which is due to the protagonist Doug reaction in not just in cut scenes and situations he finds himself in, but also when you interact with the environment around you in general in terms of dialogue.  Lastly the main strength of the Blackbay Asylum seems to be the puzzles which come in not just a mixture of reasonable difficulty, but also the creative ways you have to go about solving the puzzles by finding clues with in the environment itself which the clues presents themselves in a way that doesn’t hold your hand which helps with the overall pacing of the game and gave will give a sense of accomplishment (note: unless you have a photographic memory I would recommend pencil and paper on certain puzzles).

While I did enjoyed playing Blackbay Asylum, however the game is not flawless it does have certain glitch issues and concerns I have (best way to describe it), but in no way ruin the gaming experience but stood out which I put them into two categories neutral = +/- and negative = -:

Neutral:
+/- Screen Settings: Which it can be only be access by going back to the point where the warning content label appears.  When you get to this setting you have two screen options window and fullscreen, now window no matter what screen resolution is chosen it works while fullscreen seems to only work on the first resolution 1024 X 780.

+/- Story- The story is handled well when presented in forms journals, logs, files, letters and talking to some of the inhabitants while in general it does come across a little cliché and certain part seemed rushed; for example in one chapter Doug reminiscence’s a part of his previous life which would been interesting to see more of this in gameplay and/or story considering the ending that I saw which will make you formulate two conclusions.

+/- atmosphere- Now the game doesn’t go out of its way to necessary scare you but does provide certain type of discomfort which seems to be more of a mix bag.  For instance in the game while in birds-eye view all you can here is the music and the sounds of your footsteps will creates an eerie feeling with in the game, then once you get further enough a in gameplay event occurs which the overall execution in terms of tension was great, but there was part of me that feels that this was put in too early while the other believes the main issue is that this gameplay event doesn’t occur little bit more.  Lastly the first person view is highly variable is the best way to describe it.  I think part of the problem is from my perspective there is no type of game over if protagonist becomes too distress going into certain areas which is understandable because base off of my time playing it seems the developers goal was to immerse player’s in the environment (recommend playing this game in dark with headset on ).

Negative:
-	Only saves fully after completing chapter
-	Replay ability (note: review ends here and only represents my time playing the game and things that stood out to me which if your still not sure I recommend to read other reviews, go to the community forum to ask questions or check for any type of game updates.  And note also that experience my vary depending your OS and down below are in gameplay glitches I came across and one of them could be a potential spoiler)

Other than that the game as whole was very enjoyable and I can't wait to see what content and/or game they come up with next (:
-------------------------------------------

In game glitches:
. Occasional black screen usually occurring during the start of gameplay
. Chapter 10 had a sound glitch which upon death from boss I kept hearing the beam charge to point I had to exit the game, but this only occured once.

reviewText: Could have been something great, but it just isn't. This game is a great lesson in how some other puzzle games are so fantastic. This game has GREAT atmosphere, and a really interesting first person switching to top-down" dynamic... I could even go as far as to say the puzzles are pretty good. But a good puzzle game gives you something to go on... this game left me feeling lost on almost every.single.puzzle. Games like portal had a way of guiding the eye towards what might be a clue -- this game leaves you to pixel-hunt over and over and over. if you don't press space is the exact right spot you won't even know an object is the ONLY OBJECT YOU CAN INTERACT WITH TO PROCEED. 99.9% of the objects in the game do nothing and are just decoration
date: but scattered among them are objects that are of critical importance and there is NOTHING that suggests their significance until you've picked them up. I wanted to play thru this game
hoursPlayed: I'm just going to watch a "Let's play" online and leave it at that. Bleh."

reviewText:
This a strange one to be sure, totally unique and very enjoyable if you like your horror stories.

The premise is you are a serial killer incarcerated in an asylum. One day you find your cell door open and off you go with the 'best friend' stuffed toy the character imagines is alive. (And for those who have played 'Edna and Harvey' that's where the similarity ends). Lovecraftian horror themes develop soon after.

This is a genius mix of 3rd person point and click, first person interactive horror story and short sequences of just running away from scary monsters. The tension in the first person sections is really well judged I had a few moments where I just had to hide my eyes.

Despite the high gore content the game is not mindless. The point and click sections have some really involved puzzles and the writing of the main character is quite clever. I wouldn't say you get to like him but he's entertaining.

A few bad points:
There is no save game capability. Subchapters of the game are unlocked when you reach checkpoints and chances are your character will die a lot and keep having to backtrack a few minutes.
Oh so many typos, some of them actively confusing.

Not much more to say, it's scary and engaging. Essentially a point and click but with sections where you have to react quikly.

reviewText:
Though Blackbay Asylum may be dumb and downright ugly, the puzzles are intelligent and well thought-out.  The sound design isn't half bad either, but the regular $19.99 asking price is way too much in my opinion.

Sure, it has trading cards but the game isn't without its flaws, most notably in the form of typos and contradictions. The typos often take the form of broken English and as for 'contradictions' I believe the biggest that comes to mind is the fact that in the intro it states that Blackbay is 8 mi. off the coast of Innsmouth, Mass. yet a little later in the game there is an indication in a journal entry or pamphlet that states it's 12 mi.

That aside, I did enjoy this game and Lovecraftian themes are always a plus in my book (uber Lovecraft fans may argue that this borrows a little too heavily from HPL's lore without giving a proper shout-out to the mythos he created, such as by straight up saying that the main baddie in the game is Cthulhu...which it clearly is!!).

Regardless, as far as puzzle/adventure games go, this isn't half bad, but do yourself a favor and hold out for a sale if you do decide to get a copy.

reviewText:
All in all, I'd have to pass on this one.  If you have the chance to purchase this at $5 or so then I'd give it a whirl.

Where to start?  It's an interesting concept, using a mental asylum as the backdrop.  A serial killer who's the protagonist.  Find your way out of the asylum and figure out what's going on.

It's a concept that has been done before, and better -- Asylum I & II (Med Systems Software) in the 1980s, Sanitarium in the 1990s (available at various websites).  Radio Shack had a ghetto version of the asylum thriller called Bedlam"
date: it wasn't that good.\n\nThe view is from above
recommended: and is basically a pixel hunt and a challenge of paying attention.  It's gruesome at times

some more complicated.

I think that the main reason I would recommend against this game is the lack of a save feature.  You have to start at the beginning of a chapter each time you play.  This gets tedious.  Would it really have been that hard to add a save option?

The whole testosterone-fueled

reviewText:
Okay, I've played for roughly 2 hours so far and I'm in the middles of chapter 3. I like it. There were a few occasions when I got stuck with the puzzles. In one instance I almost gave up. But once I got past that everything was okay lol

http://youtu.be/FCLC-3d4Yik
There is no combat. It's basically a series of riddles and puzzles. The puzzles are challenging and feature quite a bit of variety. I had to sort of cheat a bit by checking the community for answers and tips.

The graphics are definitely not amazing. But I was happy with how the game looks. I thought it actually kind of looked better in first person perspective. Perhaps the whole game should be like that. However one really annoying issue with first person view for me was that the cursor would go into my outside the screen to my second screen. If I clicked while it was there the game would be minimized. This was a constant issue in first person view. I hope the dev fixes this. Yes the game is really gory which personally I generally don't really mind. But the one thing I would have liked not to have seen is the naked backside of the monster after it has passed you through it's system at the start of chapter 3. Also the game is full of jokes which I usually found amusing.

So yeah if the style and the aesthetics of the game appeals and you like puzzles then this may be a good choice for you. It's not $5 but you can probably get an adequate amount of time out of the it for your money.

reviewText: As previous comment mentionned, this game is a horror point and click without the point part. Pick objects, use them elsewhere. However, when I say horror, I mean comedy-horror. Since the character you're playing is a psychopath, everything morbid you see becomes a joke. Made me laugh some times. Is it worth at -66% ? Maybe, if you like the genre.\n\nYou should know however that the only way to save your progess is when you complete a chapter (checkpoints are only used in case you die). Puzzles can take a while to get or to find the right 'key' object needed to move on, but in the end, I highly recommend the game as an introduction to more scary games.

reviewText: Blackbay Asylum is definitely a game worth playing. It has uses many interesting and challenging puzzles that will sometimes force you to think like the psychotic Doug in order to solve them. The game also has some horror elements to it, but I found that they were only scary in the first person parts of the game, which are very few. While the game is a fun play, their are parts in were the solution to a puzzle is hidden in a corner and is very easy to miss, making it seem like the game is impossible. I don't think the game is worth twenty dollars though, wait for a sale for the game to take place before buying it if you plan to.

reviewText: Don't be fooled by the graphics, which might appear too simplistic to some people, this game is great! Actually, the crude style of the graphics and the alternating shifts from 2D to 3D perspective complement the weird story quite well. This is also no 2D/3D shooter/action game at all, but rather a strange but great mixture of adventure and puzzle game. There are only very few points in the game where timing is a bit important, the rest is definitely more brains than reflexes. Some puzzles are quite hard, but ultimately easy to figure out. There is no dedicated user save function, but in the larger levels, checkpoints are set automatically to which you return should you die. The game has auto-save after each chapter, with each chapter lasting between 3 and 15 minutes (in my playthrough at least).\nAll in all, a great Lovecraft-ian horror adventure/puzzle game that I enjoyed very very much!

reviewText:
All in all, I can't recommend this game. Not that it is a horrible game by any stretch, just not my cup of tea I guess. I got it on sale for 5$ however and if you are lucky enough to grab that up then maybe. I think I'd actually be upset had I paid full price for it.

Blackbay Asylum is a horror game set in asylum, and while asthetically that appealed to me I think the game designers could have done a better job with it's execution. But that isn't what they are all about either... It seems like their whole attitude about this game was to make it as over the line as they could...right down to the disclaimer on the opening screen.

One of the things I like most about this game is that the (hero?) is such an... unlikeable; or even evil character. I thought that was a pretty interesting spin on it and was anxious to give that a shot. The menus and dialogue are intuitive and easy to use; it's not really a hard game to play.

The biggest reason I'm not recommending this game is because of the flow of the game. The game goes from a move at your own pace speed of game to a do this now or die speed with little to no warning at times. And when you have to redo an entire chapter because you weren't quite quick enough to figure that out it's a little annoying. Some of the puzzles in this game are easy, some of them a bit more challenging; and some of them are downright bizarre and not intuitive at all. I play a lot of video games and really very seldom have to look to community guides for help, but I did have to in here. And in all fairness even after having the answer I could say yeah, I never would have thought of that.

Overall I'd rate this game about a 5 out of 10. I wish they had a step between recommend and not because to me this is neither really. It's not a horrible game, just not a good one. If you're interested, get it on sale and give it a shot. To me it would not be worth 20$ though.

reviewText: Blackbay Asylum is good. It's a lot like early Resident Evils without the action. The plot has been done so many times, I kept having flashbacks to various games when a particular beat in the story would play.  This game has a horror setting, but  isn't really a horror game. It's just a blood-soaked puzzle game. The graphics are really, really dated. The cut scenes and general animations look AT LEAST ten years old, probably more. But that doesn't really matter. The game is all about solving puzzles in order to advance. There's about half that are in the self-contained puzzle box format and about half in the environmental puzzle, where you have to find the right item and use it in the right spot. The puzzles weren't really too tough and could have actually been a little tougher. I did have to cheat once though during the 8 hours it took to finish the game. It was a simple solution that was staring me in the face that I just didn't see. The game does have some good humor to it. There's a lot of times I'd chuckle when the character would comment on non-usable items in the environment. There's just about the right amount of game here. The last couple of levels were getting dull.  The game could have benefited from a manual save option. As it stands, the game is broken up into chapters and sometimes makes you complete a whole chapter before being able to save. Normally, this isn't too bad, but the last level there is a lot of trial and error and having to keep re-doing the same parts over and over until getting it right made the last level take way longer than it should have. Overall, though, Blackbay Asylum was a fun game and puzzle adventure fans and fans of the macabre should check it out.

reviewText:
Underrated.

This game is a gem.
Heard about it long ago from Jim Sterlings playthrough and was very impressed by the style of it.

It's an adventure game with a thick atmosphere filled with gore, humorous dialog, violent nudity (saw a girl naked and eaten in half), also has cringeworthy voice acting.

I love the setting, it takes place in an insane asylum and you play as Doug, who murdered his whole family and is put behind bars. Only to find out the doctors of the place are performing experiments on all patients, even rats!
It gets nasty at times, with humans stitched upon other humans...in multiple ways.
You see rats dissected after they evolve into massive rodents.

Has great atmosphere, multiple dialogs if you keep 'inspecting' things, which nowadays adventure games don't really do anymore. It also has a lot of puzzles.

Now the puzzles for the most part, are logical. But at some points I just got so confused I had to look up some door codes or set patterns because it became frustrating going back to read a certain clue and remember it by the time you needed it. Sometimes I had no clue at all what to do even when reading the clues, but it all does really make sense but might turn off people who don't like puzzles. Make no mistake, this is a puzzle game.

Graphic wise, it reminds me of old PSX games. You play from a top down perspective, and a few levels use first person, which I could have done without.

The game runs on my toaster of a PC no problem.
it works flawlessly with my Steam Controller.

Adventure game fans would love this. So I say yeah, go for it, it is truly unique and nothing else is like it.

reviewText:
I'm not gonna lie: I went into Blackbay Asylum expecting to loathe it. Seeing some of the early gameplay and the casual racism and sexism thrown around was not exactly winning me over, never mind the visuals. However, I found out I'd picked it up somewhere along the line, probably in a bundle, and figured I'd give it a shot. Blackbay Asylum, while problematic, actually delivers quite the gameplay experience.

As quite the physical specimen and not quite the mental specimen of an asylum patient, you're given a surprise opportunity to escape Blackbay and quickly learn a lot of strange things have been going on. Between terrible things happening to other inmates/patients and walls suddenly being covered with blood and/or weird fleshy masses, things ramp up quickly in Blackbay Asylum.

Puzzle-solving and combat are fairly well balanced in the game, with the latter not coming up too often, but feeling just difficult enough when it does. The former, however, suffers from a lot of solution-integral items or spots to investigate proving much more difficult to spot visually than they really needed to be. I recommend falling back on the time-honored tradition of repeatedly investigating every little thing to make sure you don't miss such items, as frustration is easy to come by when you do. At least the puzzles are interesting despite their roughness, and the results of solving many of them is entertaining, to say the least.

What really surprised me is how the plot, about halfway through, takes a shift for an even darker, clearly Lovecraftian vibe, though this is telegraphed early on by Blackbay's geographical location. The nods to and influence from tales of old gods is very clear, and woven in more and more expertly as the later stages carry on. It feels a lot like the game's writer worked from beginning to end rather than stringing together plot points, and got progressively better at writing as they went on. It's not perfect, by any means, but it definitely improves upon the usual first impressions.

Long story short, if you can get over the offensive bits and the visuals, consider picking Blackbay Asylum up. Much like its Lovecraftian inspiration, it's clearly got problematic elements, but it's still worthwhile.

reviewText: Well, this wasn't what I expected. BA (Blackbay Asylum) is exactly what I needed at a recent time of personal horror/adventure-craving. It's not easy finding many horror games that are this scary while focusing on puzzles. Yes, BA is at its core an adventure/puzzle game. It's even comparable to Sherlock Holmes The Awakened in a few ways: puzzle-heavy game with Lovecraftian horror and Cthulhu story.\n\nPROS: Considering that most of the game is in top-down perspective, the creep factor is still huge as you wonder what you're going to come across at every corner. I say most" because a few parts of this game are in first-person. Amazingly the game brilliantly combines the two gameplay styles together without difficulty. I have to admit that Chapter 3 (in its 1st person) was a level I won't forget anytime soon; this area frightened me so much I had to take minor breaks. While I don't need breathers while replaying (knowing now what to expect) I will say the level including some horrific/bizarre imagery and edge-of-your-seat sound. You'll find more quality and depth in this one mission than the entirety of most other horror games! I also love the protagonist's endless un-PC comments whenever he interacts with something he cannot pick up. If you aren't easily offended
date: you'll get more than a few laughs. There are some good challenging puzzles which ocassionally required a walkthrough
recommended: but otherwise make you feel good as you accomplish them.\n\nCONS: Given the chapter count
hoursPlayed: you would think during the first few levels that the game is lengthy. Unfortunately it's not. Surprisingly while some chapters are long
voteText: some are ridiculously short in comparison. If you know what to do
helpfulPercent: one of them can even be completed in less than 30 seconds! The second half of the game isn't as engaging either. From the 1st Chapter your character lawnmowers a mad cook
votesHelpful: later followed by the horrifying 3rd. These left me wondering
votesTotal: could the game get any more compelling and strange? Maybe
votesFunny: but I wouldn't expect it to be less! As you delve close to the Cthulhu-mystery the game loses a lot of the shock and style that it opens up with. I liked the final boss "battle" but the final cutscene
column16: was brief and made little sense. It almost seemed very anti-climatic
column17: and this doesn't look the kind of game that aches for a sequel.\n\nOverall
column18: I enjoyed the game a lot and it's well worth a purchase. I do think there's a slight missed opportunity here though. As a Cthulhu-inspired story it had a lot of potential
column19: and the game's first half makes you think it will realise it. Though it never ceases to be fun
column20: I did feel a bit let down towards the end with the lack of horrifying build-up. Maybe I was expecting too much
column21: but when the first few levels really displayed something special I would hope the game persisted from there. Still
column22: if you're looking for some challenging puzzles filled with memorable and horrific moments then BA might be the right choice!\n\n77/100"
